messages:
Thought provoking quote by Carl Jung.

Visit --> www.all-about-psychology.com/carl_jung.html to learn all about the life and work of Carl Jung and access free full-text articles by Jung e.g, The Association Method. Timeline Photos.

It was on this day, March 3, 1907 that Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung met for the first time. They talked for 13 hours without interruption. The meeting took place at Freud's apartment (Berggasse 19), located in the Alsergrund district of Vienna.

Love this! Meet 1940’s comic book hero Larry Hunter a young psychology professor and expert on the human brain who is headed for strange adventures! What’s not to like? The image is taken from the comic story "The Adventure of The Mad Genius" described as follows: 

"Professor Larry Hunter is detoured on his way to a lecture and is imprisoned by Dr. Z, who has been studying the same topics of thought reception. Dr. Z forces Larry to work to complete his thought receiver, but with the help of fellow captive Mary Brown and the now-working receiver, Larry and Mary both escape. Larry vows to use the receiver to fight crime." Timeline Photos.

Mind blowing illusion created by Koukichi Sugihara from the Meiji Institute for Advanced Study of Mathematical Sciences, Japan. Official description/explantion was as follows:

"In this video, wooden balls roll up the slopes just as if they are pulled by a magnet. The behavior of the balls seems impossible, because it is against the gravity. The video is not a computer graphic, but a real scene. What is actually happening is that the orientations of the slopes are perceived oppositely, and hence the descending motion is misinterpreted as ascending motion. This illusion is remarkable in that it is generated by a three-dimensional solid object and physical motion, instead of a two-dimensional picture."

There is a page dedicated to optical illusions over at the main website. See following link.

If you are lucky enough to be visting the Edinburgh festival this year make sure you book to see Richard Wiseman's Psychobabble talk at the Assembly Rooms on Sunday 4th August. See following link for full details. 

https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/spoken-word/richard-wiseman-psychobabble
   
Here's the official description:

Best-selling author, psychologist and magician Richard Wiseman rummages around in your mind. Discover how to tell lies, read thoughts and transform a tea towel into a chicken. Several laughs. No Powerpoint. ***** 'you won’t want to miss Psychobabble' (FringeGuru.com). Richard holds Britain’s only Professorship in the Public Understanding of Psychology and researches an eclectic range of topics including luck, self help, illusion and persuasion. Over 2 million people have taken part in his mass participation experiments and he's acted as creative consultant to Derren Brown, The MythBusters, The Mentalist, Heston Blumenthal, Nick Cave and Jeremy Deller.

Why are innocent people wrongfully convicted in certain cases yet acquitted in others? Research is starting to uncover what happens. A new study led Dr. Jon Gould, "Predicting Erroneous Convictions: A Social Science Approach to Miscarriages of Justice" compared cases where innocent defendants were wrongfully convicted to "near misses" – cases in which an innocent defendant was acquitted or had charges dismissed before trial. 

See following link to read/download a PDF of the full study (434 pages).

https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/grants/241389.pdf. Timeline Photos.

As promised, more information relating to my last post "The Univited Wedding Guests." 

First of all the picture isn't fake. As is often the case with strange things like this, many people believe that the twelve creepy figures on the balacony represent something paranormal e.g., ghosts, evil spirits, messengers of the apocalypse etc. 

The truth, however, is much more rational. The figures are simply part of an art exhibition by Dawn Dedeaux - ironically entitled, ‘The Goddess Fortuna and Her Dunces in an Effort to Make Sense of It All’ - see following link for full details. 

http://hyperallergic.com/41565/dawn-dedeaux-prospect-2/

Abnormal psychology information and resources - see following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/abnormal-psychology.html

(Photo Credit: Trois Têtes) Timeline Photos.

See following link to learn how to tell the difference between a fake and a genuine smile.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/duchenne-smile.html. Timeline Photos.

See following link for a great article on how modern technology has provided a fresh perspective on one of the most famous case studies in the history of psychology and neuroscience.

http://bit.ly/PhineasGage. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/

See following link for a great collection of body language quotes.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/body-language-quotes.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/anxiety-disorders.html

See following link (http://bbc.in/AnxietyMentors) to listen to a recent episode of the BBC radio series All in The Mind in which presenter claudia Hammdond reports on an innovative mentoring project where people with social phobia, agoraphobia or other anxiety disorders are matched up with volunteer mentors who've been through, and are mostly recovered from their own experiences of anxiety.

For more information on anxiety disorders there is a section dedicated to the topic over at the All About Psychology website - see following link for details.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/anxiety-disorders.html

(Photo Credit: Ricardo Motti) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/

See following link to read a very interesting article by Vaughan Bell on the validity of the polygraph.

http://bit.ly/PolygraphArticle

(Photo Credit: Josh Bancroft) Timeline Photos.

I've just added a page on mindfulness to the Transpersonal Psychology section of the main website. See following link for full details.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/mindfulness.html. Timeline Photos.

Research findings by Adrian Aguilera and Ricardo Muñoz - psychologists at the University of California, Berkeley - indicate that automated text-messaging as an adjunct to cognitive–behavioral therapy has the potential to improve mental health care broadly, and among low-income populations specifically.

See following link to learn more.

http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2012/04/09/text-messaging/

(Photo Credit: Daveybot) Timeline Photos.

See following link to learn more about this enduring human tendency.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/pareidolia.html. Timeline Photos.

Excellent National Institute of Justice information and guidance on giving expert testimony. Includes access to a free online 13 module training course.

Although designed for forensic experts, this great resource will also be helpful to psychologists who have limited experience testifying in court.

See following link for full details.

http://www.all-about-forensic-science.com/forensic-expert-witness.html. Timeline Photos.

Determining Optimal Interventions For Children Who Struggle With Reading:

Primliminary findings from a recently published study by Professor Laurie Cutting and colleagues from Vanderbilt University suggest that reading and plasticity in the brain could lay the foundation for targeted investigations into what types of training works best for particular readers.

See following link for more details.

http://news.vanderbilt.edu/2012/04/fmri-word-learning/ Timeline Photos.

Research findings by Matthew Feinberg, Dacher Keltner and Jennifer Stellar - psychologists at the University of California, Berkeley - suggest that there are positive aspects to rumor-mongering which include helping us police bad behavior, preventing exploitation and lowering stress.

See following link to learn more.

http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2012/01/17/gossip/ Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

See following link to connect with websites which list psychology related job vacancies.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-jobs.html

(Photo Credit: Zach Klein) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Psychology and law information guide. See following link for full details.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/psychology-and-law.html. Timeline Photos.

Scientists Tap The Genius of Children:

UC Berkeley researchers are tapping the cognitive functioning of babies, toddlers and preschoolers to program computers to think more like humans. See following link for full story.

http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2012/03/12/babyeinsteins/

(Photo Credit: Bruce Turner) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

I've just updated the optical illusions page over at the main All About Psychology website. The page includes a fascinating video featuring cognitive neuroscientist Al Seckel, widely regarded as one of the world's leading authorities on visual and sensory illusions. See following link for details.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/optical-illusions.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/common-dreams.html

What common dreams do you have?

(Photo Credit: Michael Chen) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Earworms: The Psychology of Tunes That Stick in Our Heads.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17105759

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-research.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

http://bit.ly/ConsciousnessPodcast. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

If you're interested in the life and work of Sigmund Freud, make sure you check out the Freud Museum website which has a comprehensive education section where you can learn out all about:

Psychoanalysis
Freud & Religion
Freud & War Neuroses
Interpretation of Dreams
Anna Freud

See following link for full details.

http://www.freud.org.uk/education/topics/ Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/clinical-psychology.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

http://bit.ly/VSRamachandran. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

The psychology magazine article collection forms part of a wider initiative on the All About Psychology website to make important, insightful and engaging public domain works freely available. See following link for full details.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-magazine.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/francis-galton-psychology.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Primed by Expectations: Why A Classic Psychology Experiment Isn’t What It Seemed. See following link to read about a modern take on an old classic.

http://bit.ly/CleverHans. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Don't forget! to visit the psychology mnemonics page over at the main website (see following link). http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-mnemonics.html. The Power of Mnemonics. You can trick your mind into remembering useful but dull facts by weaving the information into vivid mental shorthand.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Great set of free resource materials courtesy of OpenLearn designed to help students get the most out of their course, program or degree. Learning materials include information on:

Learning how to learn, revision and examinations, presentations, developing your thinking skills and essay and report writing.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-study-skills.html. Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

Great confirmation bias quote by Dr. Carol Tavris.

(Photo Credit: joe.ross via flickr creative commons)

#psychology #ConfirmationBias. Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

See following link to read a comprehensive full-text, open-access journal article by Peter DeScioli & Robert Kurzban which explores the cognitive systems underlying human friendship.

www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0005802

(Photo Credit: Leland Francisco Via Flickr Creative Commons)

#psychology #psychologyarticle #humanfriendship. Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

See following link to read a comprehensive full-text journal article by Stephan Lewandowsky and colleagues which reviews recent psychological science detailing common sources of misinformation, processes for evaluating the validity of new information, and strategies for combating the effects of misinformation.

http://psi.sagepub.com/content/13/3/106.full.pdf+html?ijkey=FNCpLYuivUOHE&keytype=ref&siteid=sppsi

(Photo Credit: Fybrid Photos Via Flickr Creative Commons) Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

Latest pareidolia image i.e. the perception of an ambiguous and random stimulus as significant.

(Photo Credit: Cennydd via flickr creative commons) Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

See following link to read an interesting social identity and crowd psychology study exploring the spread of applause following an academic presentation.

http://rsif.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/10/85/20130466.full

(Photo Credit: \!/_PeacePlusOne via flickr creative commons) Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

See following link to read a comprehensive full-text, open-access journal article by Aldert Vrij, Par Anders Granhag & Stephen Porter which discusses some of the common misconceptions about lying (for example, the belief that people telling lies are more nervous), reviews the shortcomings of commonly used lie-detection techniques, and presents new empirically supported methods for recognizing lies with greater accuracy.

www.psychologicalscience.org/journals/pspi/pspi_10_6.pdf

(Photo Credit: Sergio Bertolini Via Flickr Creative Commons) Timeline Photos.

www.all-about-psychology.com

See link below to read a free full-text journal article exploring the processes that underpin moral judgment.

http://www.scirp.org/journal/PaperDownload.aspx?paperID=26497

(Photo Credit: Quinn Dombrowski via Flickr Creative Commons) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

See following link to read a very useful full-text journal article in which the authors discuss 10 learning techniques in detail and offer recommendations concerning their relative utility.

http://psi.sagepub.com/content/14/1/4.full.pdf+html?ijkey=Z10jaVH/60XQM&keytype=ref&siteid=sppsi

(Photo Credit: cstrom via flickr creative commons) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

See following link to read a full-text, open-access journal article which suggests that merit-based sharing is apparent in young children.

http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0043979

(Photo Credit: Juli Crockett via flickr creative commons) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

See link below for a conversation with (or video, or audio if you prefer) University Professor Daniel C. Dennett, Co-Director at the Center for Cognitive Studies, Tufts University and author of over three hundred scholarly articles on various aspects on the mind.

http://edge.org/conversation/normal-well-tempered-mind

(Photo Credit: Saad Faruque via flickr creative commons) Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

(Photo Credit: Michaël Korchia via flickr creative commons) Timeline Photos.

ON THIS DAY IN THE HISTORY OF PSYCHOLOGY (30th October 1938)

A radio adaptation of the H.G. Wells classic The War of the Worlds was broadcast across the United States. The dramatization was so realistic it was said to have resulted in mass hysteria. The events following the broadcast became the focus of Hadley Cantril's book "The Invasion from Mars: A Study in the Psychology of Panic."

WANT TO BE HAPPY? SLOW DOWN

Great article which includes links to some excellent TED talks. Want to be happy? Slow down. In this free-wheeling discussion at TED Global in October 2014, Buddhist monk Matthieu Ricard talked with journalist and writer Pico Iyer about how to spend time meaningfully.

all-about-psychology.com

Great TED talk in which Stanford University Psychologist, Professor Carol Dweck outlines her pioneering research on the self-conceptions (or mindsets) people use to structure the self and guide their behavior. The Power of Believing That You Can Improve.

www.all-about-psychology.com

Excellent TED article by Stanford University psychologist Kelly McGonigal. How to be good at stress. What does it mean to be “good” at stress? Does it mean that you don’t get stressed out? That you stay calm under pressure and bounce back from adversity?

all-about-psychology.com

Fab TED talk on procrastination. Inside the mind of a master procrastinator. Tim Urban knows that procrastination doesn't make sense, but he's never been able to shake his habit of waiting until the last minute to get things done. In this hilarious and insightful talk, Urban takes us on a journey through YouTube binges, Wikipedia rabbit holes and bouts of staring out the win….

all-about-psychology.com

Quote from a great TED talk by psychologist Jonathan Haidt which you can watch here --> bit.ly/self-transcendence. Timeline Photos.

all-about-psychology.com

Brilliant TED Talk by Joachim de Posada discussing Walter Mischel's classic psychology experiment on self control. Don't eat the marshmallow!

all-about-psychology.com

Via: TED - Ideas Worth spreading. How to turn small talk into smart conversation. Tips from a comedian and a journalist on the art of going from small talk to big ideas. Try these out at the next summer wedding reception.

all-about-psychology.com

Interesting Big Think article on Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck's work on 'mindset' A Simple Principle of Educational Psychology Has Been Massively Misunderstood | Big Think. The psychologist who fundamentally changed how teachers talk to children warns her message has been lost in translation.

all-about-psychology.com

Great TED talk by cognitive scientist Laura Schulz, whose developmental behavior studies are changing our notions of how children learn. The surprisingly logical minds of babies. How do babies learn so much from so little so quickly? In a fun, experiment-filled talk, cognitive scientist Laura Schulz shows how our young ones make decisions with a surprisingly strong sense of logic, well before they can talk.

all-about-psychology.com

Great TED talk by neuroscientist Dr. Daniel Levitin on how to avoid making critical mistakes in stressful situations. How to stay calm when you know you'll be stressed. You're not at your best when you're stressed. In fact, your brain has evolved over millennia to release cortisol in stressful situations, inhibiting rational, logical thinking but potentially helping you survive, say, being attacked by a lion. Neuroscientist Daniel Levitin thinks there's a way to av….

all-about-psychology.com

TED talk on how to build a fulfilling, long life by Robert Waldinger, director of the Harvard Study of Adult Development, one of the most comprehensive longitudinal studies in history. What makes a good life? Lessons from the longest study on happiness.

But somewhere along the way, things took a turn. In this passionate, eloquent talk, Ronson explains how t….

Brilliant TED talk by psychologist Guy Winch, PhD, who asks us to take our emotional and psychological health as seriously as we take our physical health. The case for emotional hygiene.

Studying Psychology? GO HERE --> www.all-about-psychology.com

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF YOUR FUTURE SELF

Great TED Talk by Harvard psychologist Dan Gilbert. The psychology of your future self. "Human beings are works in progress that mistakenly think they're finished." Dan Gilbert shares recent research on a phenomenon he calls the "end of history illusion," where we somehow imagine that the person we are right now is the person we'll be for the rest of time. Hint: that's not the case.

www.all-about-psychology.com

Psychology TED talks video playlist. Psychology TED Talks. A wonderfully diverse collection of psychology related videos from one my all time favorite websites.

HOW JURIES ARE FOOLED BY STATISTICS Via TED. www.ted.com. Oxford mathematician Peter Donnelly reveals the common mistakes humans make in interpreting statistics -- and the devastating impact these errors can have on the outcome of criminal trials.

UNSTOPPABLE LEARNING via TED Radio Hour

Why do we put so much effort in making kids think and act like us? TED speakers explore the different ways babies and children learn — from the womb, to the playground, to the web. Unstoppable Learning.

THE BIRTH OF A WORD

www.ted.com/talks/deb_roy_the_birth_of_a_word

Cognitive scientist and MIT researcher Deb Roy wanted to understand how his infant son learned language — so he wired up his house with videocameras to catch every moment and parsed 90,000 hours of home video to watch "gaaaa" slowly turn into "water." Astonishing, data-rich research with deep implications for how we learn. Fascinating TED talk. Timeline Photos.

For over a hundred years the Gifford Lecture series has been one of the foremost academic forums dealing with religion, science and philosophy. In 2009 Neuroscientist and professor of psychology Michael Gazzaniga delivered 6 lectures under the series title: The Science of Mind Constraining Matter.

Lecture 1: What We Are? 

Lecture 2: The Distributed Cerebral Networks of Mind.

Lecture 3: The Brain Divided: Discovering The "Interpreter."

Lecture 4: The Meaning of Being Free.

Lecture 5: The Social Brain.

Lecture 6: We Are The Law.

In courtrooms, eyewitness testimony is considered extremely powerful. But should it be? Scott Fraser explains why, even when witnesses feel sure they are telling a true story, or making the right identification, their minds could be playing tricks on them - filling in blanks in traumatic memories with erroneous information.

Fraser is a forensic psychologist who thinks deeply about the fallibility of human memory and encourages a more scientific approach to trial evidence.

www.youtube.com/user/LearnAboutPsychology. The Divided Brain. Psychiatrist Iain McGilchrist describes the real differences between the left and right halves of the human brain. It's not simply "emotion on the right, reason on the left," but something far more complex and interesting.

Dow realized that a surprising number of death row inmates had similar biographies. In this talk he proposes a bold plan, one that prevents murders in the first place.

How do you remember where you parked your car? How do you know if you're moving in the right direction? Neuroscientist Neil Burgess studies the neural mechanisms that map the space around us, and how they link to memory and imagination.

For more fascinating videos, see following link to visit the All About Psychology YouTube Channel. 

http://www.youtube.com/user/LearnAboutPsychology. How Your Brain Tells You Where You Are.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Yale Fox researches social nightclub behaviour with a particular emphasis on music and how it affects people at an implicit level. With a background in biology, psychology, and sociology, Fox investigates such topics as how music can affect bar sales and people's ability to multitask, how it determines listening patterns, and how the stock market can affect mood, which in turn predicts the characteristics of popular music. 

Fox's research has been published in international publications, documentaries, and textbooks. Additionally, Yale's position in the nightclub industry gives him access to a vast quantity of unique data, which has already led to some remarkable conclusions.

For more information on this fascinating research, check out Yale Fox's blog on the science of nightlife - http://www.darwinvsthemachine.com/

all-about-psychology.com/william-james-psychology.html

In 1905 legendary psychologist William James published a tribute to the memory of his very good friend and eminent philosopher Thomas Davidson. Within his tribute James referred to a letter Davidson had written in which he summed up the results of his own experience of life by way of a series of maxims. This was one of those pearls of wisdom. Timeline Photos.

Psychology of Music: What Does it For You?

In preparing for an interview I'm conducting with Yale Fox, I learned from an article he'd written entitled - Why We Experience Goosebumps During A Piece Of Music We Love? -  that the pleasant feeling of chills running up your spine are called "Frissons."

This got me thinking about music that gives me Frissons. The tune that does it for me everytime is Bizzare Love Triangle by New Order (http://youtu.be/W2Ii0K77K1k). 

The eighties was my decade and this anthem transports me straight back there everytime, in fact I've got Frissons right now just thinking about it. 

So What Does it For You? What's your Frisson number one? Post your answer here. I'm sure Yale will be very interested in the results.

'Unmasked: A Revealing Look At The Fascinating World Of Body Language' is a quick read on body language. I'm extremely pleased to announce that Dr. Desmond Morris is now featured on the All About Body Language website. A pioneer in the scientific understanding of body language, his groundbreaking book ‘The Naked Ape’ is in the top hundred bestsellers of all time having sold over 10 million copies worldwide.

In addition to agreeing to be interviewed, Dr. Morris also very kindly provided us with some wonderful body language images and granted us permission to publish an extract from his memoirs. See following link for full details.

If you're interested in body language and nonverbal communication you will be pleased to know that my very good friend and author Craig James Baxter has kindly agreed to make the kindle version of his International #1 Best Seller - Behind The Mask: What Michael Jackson's Body Language Told The World - available for free (TODAY ONLY). See following link.

http://www.amazon.com/dp/B009LAMGDY

Craig is a trained micro expressions reader with an extensive background in anatomy and physiology who has interviewed the world's leading body language experts (Paul Ekman, David Matsumoto, Carol Kinsey Goman, J.J. Newberry etc.)

Craig's book has received a host of excellent independent reviews. For instance, former FBI spy-catcher Joe Navarro, - recognized as one of the world’s foremost authorities on reading non-verbal communications - wrote:

"Treat yourself to Behind The Mask: What Michael Jackson's Body Language Told The World by Craig Baxter. Whether you are a Michael Jackson fan or a student of nonverbal communications, you will enjoy reading this well researched and documented book." 

Remember, the book is only available for free download today (December 17th).

If you don't have a kindle you can read the book on your computer or mobile device via Amazon's free Kindle reading apps. See following link for details.

http://www.amazon.com/gp/feature.html/ref=dig_arl_box?ie=UTF8&docId=1000493771

Fascinating talk by social psychologist Amy Cuddy whose research on body language reveals that we can change other people’s perceptions - and even our own body chemistry - simply by changing body positions.

If you would like to learn more about body language and non-verbal communication - see following link for free and comprehensive information and resources.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/ Your Body Language Shapes Who You Are.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/

Just wanted to say congratulations to my very good friend Craig James Baxter. His recently published body language book is getting great independent reviews and has already hit the best seller list.

Personally speaking I think the most compelling and poignant aspect of the book is the notion that despite being one of the most famous, successful and revered individuals of all time, Michael Jackson's non-verbal repertoire (gestures, expressions, behavioral movements, emotional indicators etc) were no different to anybody else.

You can get full details of Craig's book via the following link.

http://www.amazon.com/dp/B009LAMGDY

For free and comprehensive information and resources on body langauge and non-verbal communication - including interviews with the world's leading body language experts, visit http://www.all-about-body-language.com/ Timeline Photos.

If you're interested in the analysis of body language and non-verbal communication then make sure you add this to your reading list. I know the author Craig James Baxter from our collaboration on the website http://www.all-about-body-language.com/ and having read a draft version of this book I'd say its got bestseller written all over it.

In the course of the book, Craig employs his body language expertise and extensive background knowledge in anatomy and physiology to analyze Michael Jackson's body language during: 

His interview with Oprah Winfrey. 

His Statement from Neverland Ranch. 

His 1996 Police interview.

His "Living with Michael Jackson" interview with Martin Bashir.

If you want to learn more about the fascinating world of body language and non-verbal communication you will love this book. If you're a Michael Jackson fan you need to read this book.

A kindle version of the book is due to be released in October. If you would like notifying as soon as it's available you can leave your details via the following link.

http://www.youtube.com/user/AboutBodyLanguage

If you're interested in learning more about body language and non-verbal communication make sure you visit the About Body Language YouTube channel. You'll find lots of fascinating material on the subject including a three part tutorial series on lying and deception and video playlists featuring leading body language experts e.g., Paul Ekman, Joe Navarro and Dr. David Matsumoto etc.

You can visit and subscribe to the Body Language YouTube channel for free via the following link.

http://www.youtube.com/user/AboutBodyLanguage. Timeline Photos.

Just wanted to say many congratulations to my friend and website co-host Craig-James Baxter whose body language YouTube channel has just hit 1,000,000 views - an amazing achievement! For more information on James and all things body language please visit http://www.all-about-body-language.com/. Timeline Photos.

I'm delighted to announce the launch of the official About Body Language YouTube channel. As well as showcasing specific playlists, we will also be uploading a series of exclusive videos. Each of these videos will offer body language tips and advice that anybody can use to positive effect in all important aspects of their interactions with other people (relationships, job interviews etc). You can visit and subscribe to the About Body Language YouTube channel for free via the following link.

http://www.youtube.com/user/AboutBodyLanguage. About Body Language YouTube Channel.

First half of a fascinating presentation by body language & micro expressions expert Craig-James Baxter. Please note that the audio quality on the video isn't the greatest and you may need to turn up your speakers. The presentation begins about 1 minute 30 seconds into the video. 

See following link for more free and comprehensive information on body language.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/ How to Spot Lying & Deception.

Following on from my last post, a very warm welcome to http://www.all-about-body-language.com/. I had originally planned just to have a body language section on my psychology website but such is the scope and range of this fascinating topic it soon became clear that it needed a dedicated website to do justice to all the things we intend to cover. I say we because I am extremely fortunate to be developing the website in collaboration with Craig-James Baxter.

Craig is a master trainer in reading advanced micro expressions and is one of the most viewed body language decoders in YouTube’s history, having complied nearly 100 body language analysis videos featuring celebrities, politicians, musicians and high profile criminology cases.

If you're interested in learning more about body language the site already has plenty of information and resources available: Including:

Body language analysis videos
Body language guides
Body language tips
Body language Q & A
Body language articles

And that's just the beginning, we've got some amazing things lined-up, such as exclusive interviews with some of the leading body language experts in the world.

I really hope you enjoy exploring our new website.

Please help us get the word out by liking and sharing this post.

As always, many thanks for your support.

David

KANIZSA TRIANGLE

messages:
FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (14th November)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00X0LX6QG

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00X0LX6QG (UK)

This memoir is a recollection of powerful recovery based information from Steve Colori's experiences with facing and overcoming schizoaffective disorder. Steve has published seven articles with Oxford Medical Journals on Schizoaffective disorder and five of these are within this text. 

To have schizoaffective disorder a patient has to be diagnosed with all the symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder simultaneously. Steve's memoir is well-written, insightful, and fascinating and is useful for patients, family members, and medical staff. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (30th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00OHHTRSS

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00OHHTRSS (UK)

A fascinating historical account, Psychopathic Personality: Report of a Case was originally presented by Dr. Martin Peck at a meeting of the Boston Society of Neurology and Psychiatry, on November 17th, 1921. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (28th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00DL6HL3Y

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00DL6HL3Y (UK)

Originally published in 1948, Superstition in The Pigeon is a learning theory classic. Shortly after its publication, Skinner gave a detailed account of his science of behavior in a paper titled Are Theories of Learning Necessary? This paper is also presented in full. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (27th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00GSNPEHM

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00GSNPEHM (UK)

Craig James Baxter (author of two previous Amazon best-selling books on body language) has developed this useful, practical guide designed to help you develop and improve your knowledge of human behaviour. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (24th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00OQ93KK8

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00OQ93KK8 (UK)

This classic paper on group behavior was originally presented in the form of a lecture in 1916. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (18th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B009ZC2UOS

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B009ZC2UOS (UK)

Drawing on the author's experience as both a student and then a University lecturer in Psychology, this guide is designed to inform psychology students at every stage of their educational journey. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY!

www.amazon.com/dp/B00BSY6WGI

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00BSY6WGI (UK)

Originally published in 1946 Significant Aspects of Client-Centered Therapy is essential reading for anybody interested in psychotherapy and counseling. In this landmark publication Carl Rogers outlines the origins of client-centered therapy, the process of client-centered therapy, the discovery and capacity of the client and the client-centered nature of the therapeutic relationship.

Bonus Content:

Significant Aspects of Client-Centered Therapy builds upon some of Carl Rogers' previously published work. Among the most notable of these earlier articles were The Processes of Therapy and The Development of Insight in A Counseling Relationship; both of which are also presented in full. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (14th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00C6IX42A

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00C6IX42A (UK)

Despite his premature death at the age of just 37, Lev Vygotsky is widely considered as one of the leading developmental psychologists of the 20th century. In addition to his seminal contribution to the relationship between language and thought, Lev Vygotsky also put forward ideas regarding the psychology of play, in particular the process of self-regulation through creative play.

This classic article which was originally given in the form of a speech provides several key insights into Lev Vygotsky's theories of play. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (13th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00OG550S2

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00OG550S2 (UK)

A fascinating account of phobias, sentiments and obsessions occurring in the course of neuroses, The Fear of Action was originally presented as a paper by Pierre Janet at the Atlantic City meeting of the American Psychopathological Society in June, 1921. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (12th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00X0LX6QG

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00X0LX6QG (UK)

This memoir is a recollection of powerful recovery based information from Steve Colori's experiences with facing and overcoming schizoaffective disorder. Steve has published seven articles with Oxford Medical Journals on Schizoaffective disorder and five of these are within this text. 

To have schizoaffective disorder a patient has to be diagnosed with all the symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder simultaneously. Steve's memoir is well-written, insightful, and fascinating and is useful for patients, family members, and medical staff. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (10th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00LLHOXY0

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00LLHOXY0 (UK)

A classic in the history of psychology - Perception: An Introduction To The Gestalt Theory was the first paper Kurt Koffka wrote in English. It was also the first article on Gestalt psychology to be published in an American journal when it appeared in the Psychological Bulletin in October 1922. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (9th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00DYUMU38

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00DYUMU38 (UK)

Featuring contributions from some of the most influential and enigmatic thinkers of the 20th century, (Rogers, Shaffer, Ellis, Rosenthal, Bandura, Szasz) Psychotherapy Classics: Landmark Articles in the History of Psychotherapy and Counseling is essential reading for anybody with an interest in this area. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (8th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00LOWNXG6

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00LOWNXG6 (UK)

Described by eminent psychologist Richard Gregory as "perhaps the most famous experiment in the whole of experimental psychology," George Malcolm Stratton spent several days continuously wearing specially adapted lenses which inverted his visual image up and down and left and right. Stratton's novel and pioneering studies served as a catalyst for research into binocular vision and depth perception which continues to this day. 

Between November 1896 and September 1897 Stratton published his experimental aims and experiences in the Psychological Review, the full details of which are contained herein. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (5th September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00OHHTRSS

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00OHHTRSS (UK)

A fascinating historical account, Psychopathic Personality: Report of a Case was originally presented by Dr. Martin Peck at a meeting of the Boston Society of Neurology and Psychiatry, on November 17th, 1921. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (3rd September)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00DL6HL3Y

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00DL6HL3Y (UK)

Originally published in 1948, Superstition in The Pigeon is a learning theory classic. Shortly after its publication, Skinner gave a detailed account of his science of behavior in a paper titled Are Theories of Learning Necessary? This paper is also presented in full. Timeline Photos.

FREE ON KINDLE TODAY! (2nd September)

In honor of today being John B Watson's birthday the kindle version of Conditioned Emotional Reactions (The Case of Little Albert) is available for free until 11:59 PM Pacific Standard Time. (January 9th)

www.amazon.com/dp/B00BOVL3TQ (USA)

www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00BOVL3TQ (UK)

Conditioned Emotional Reactions by John B. Watson and Rosalie Rayner is one of the most influential, infamous and iconic research articles ever published in the history of psychology. Commonly referred to as "The Case of Little Albert" this psychology classic attempted to show how fear could be induced in an infant through classical conditioning. 

Bonus Material:

One of the most dramatic aspects of Watson and Rayner's original study was that they had planned to test a number of methods by which they could remove Little Albert's conditioned fear responses. However, as Watson noted "Unfortunately Albert was taken from the hospital the day the above tests were made. Hence the opportunity of building up an experimental technique by means of which we could remove the conditioned emotional responses was denied us."

This unforeseen turn of events was something that obviously stayed with Watson, as under his guidance some three years later, Mary Cover Jones conducted a follow-up study - A Laboratory Study of Fear: The Case of Peter - which illustrated how fear may be removed under laboratory conditions. This additional and highly relevant article is also presented in full.  

If you live outside the USA/UK, just go the Amazon website in your country and type the book title into the search box.

Originally published in 1946 it was in this landmark publication where Carl Rogers outlined the origins of client-centered therapy, the process of client-centered therapy, the discovery and capacity of the client and the client-centered nature of the therapeutic relationship.

Bonus Content:

Significant Aspects of Client-Centered Therapy builds upon some of Carl Rogers' previously published work. Among the most notable of these earlier articles were The Processes of Therapy and The Development of Insight in A Counseling Relationship; both of which are also presented in full.

A trained micro expressions reader with an extensive background in anatomy and physiology, author Craig-James Baxter has been sharing his knowledge and passion for body language for over 8 years. He has interviewed the world's leading body language experts (Desmond Morris, Paul Ekman, Joe Navarro, David Matsumoto, Carol Kinsey Goman, J.J. Newberry); written for numerous magazines and newspapers and has over 1,000,000 views on YouTube to his name.

In Behind The Mask: What Michael Jackson's Body Language Told The World - Craig-James Baxter's analysis of five infamous video interviews offers a fresh and compelling insight into the world of one of the most popular musicians the world has ever known. 

The interviews covered in the book are: 

1993 Oprah Winfrey Interview. 
1993 Statement from Neverland Ranch. 
1996 Police interview. 
2003 Martin Bashir: Living with Michael Jackson.
2003 Take Two: The Footage You Were Never Meant to See (Martin Bashir Rebuttal Video).

"Transmission of Aggression Through Imitation of Aggressive Models." More commonly known as "The Bobo Doll Experiment," was the first study to explore the impact of televised violence on children. RETROACTIVE MEMORY FALSIFICATION

I'm listening to the compelling verdict statement in the Oscar Pistorius trial. Judge Thokozile Masipa noted 'probability some witnesses failed to separate what they knew personally from what they gathered in media.' This very same issue raised during a murder trial in 1896 was a defining moment in the history of forensic psychology

For more information and resources on the psychopathic behavior visit the All About Forensic Psychology website - see following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/psychopath.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/

A comprehensive guide to the world of forensic psychology.

Highlights on the website include:

A detailed and clear account of what forensic psychology actually is. Important because of the way the subject has been distorted, sensationalised and inaccurately presented in books, films and on TV. See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/what-is-forensic-psychology.html

A series of information pages on criminal profiling. A fascinating subject to learn about in iteslf but also important to know of its place within forensic psychology; for example is criminal profiling a realistic career goal? See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/fbi-profiler.html

The Forensic Psychology Degree Directory. A great resource for anybody thinking about studying forensic psychology. See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/forensic-psychology-degree.html

Free full-text articles. A wonderful collection of publications including a special "Inside the Criminal Mind" collection showcasing all the major articles written by members of the Behavioral Science Units, National Center for the Analysis of Violent Crime, at the FBI Academy. See following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/forensic-psychology-ebook.html

I really hope that you find all the information and resources on the All About Forensic Psychology website useful and engaging.

David Webb BSc (hons), MSc. Forensic Psychology.

http://www.amazon.com/dp/B008O64S5U

I've just published The Essential Guide To Criminal Profiling on the kindle. The guide is based on a series of classes I gave as part of an undergraduate program in forensic psychology.

The guide explores a range of topics including, the origins of criminal profiling, FBI profiling, methodology and effectiveness and whether becoming a profiler is a realistic career choice.

As with my other kindle publications, the proceeds from any sales will go towards the running and hosting costs associated with the four websites built around my teaching and research interests.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/

http://www.all-about-forensic-science.com/

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/

See following link for full details on The Essential Guide To Criminal Profiling.

http://www.amazon.com/dp/B008O64S5U. Timeline Photos.

https://www.amazon.com/author/david-webb

I'm excited to announce that I've just published The Quick Guide To Forensic Psychology in the Amazon Kindle store. This clear and concise guide will save you time looking for information relating to the issues that matter and provides access to great free resources and additional information links that will allow you to learn as much about forensic psychology as you would like. Topics covered in the guide include:

What is forensic psychology?

The History of Forensic Psychology.

What Does A Forensic Psychologist Do?

Forensic Psychology Careers Information.

Where To Study Forensic Psychology.

Quality Forensic Psychology Links.

The quick Guide To Forensic Psychology will cost you less than a dollar (slightly more if local sales tax is added in your country), the proceeds of which will go towards running and hosting the four websites built around my teaching and research interests.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/

http://www.all-about-forensic-science.com/

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/

For more details of The Quick Guide To Forensic Psychology see following link.  

http://www.amazon.com/dp/B008I6330M

The Quick Guide To Forensic Psychology is the first in a series of titles I'm currently working on. To keep right up-to-date with all the latest developments please visit my Amazon author page. https://www.amazon.com/author/david-webb

As always, many thanks for your support.

David. Timeline Photos.

The Open Access Journal of Forensic Psychology is a professional, peer-reviewed journal created by and for forensic psychologists. It is free to anyone with Internet access. See following link for full deatils of this excellent resource.

http://www.forensicpsychologyunbound.ws/OAJFP/Home.html

For more free and comprehensive information on forensic psychology head over to http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/ Timeline Photos.

Can't wait to see this! Experimenter. See Peter Sarsgaard as Stanley Milgram in Experimenter with Winona Ryder, Jim Gaffigan, Kellan Lutz, Dennis Haysbert, Taryn Manning and Anton Yelchin.

I'm sure (and hope) that nobody who follows this page seriously thought the world was going to end one year ago today - but what about all the people who were convinced that it would? How did they cope with the realization that the only thing destroyed on the 21st of December 2012 was their strongly held belief. 

Enter Cognitive Dissonance - a robust psychological mechanism which helps resolve states of inner tension triggered by logically inconsistent ways of thinking.

And as far as inconsistent thinking goes; thinking that the world is definitely going to end on a certain day, only for it to not, is about as inconsistent as it gets. The brilliant psychologist Leon Festinger was acutely aware of this back in 1956 when he infiltrated a group who believed that the world was about to end but that the members of the group would be rescued by a flying saucer.

When the prophecy failed, this was explained by the group leader as being down to the fact that the group had "spread so much light" that God had spared the planet. The group then set about spreading the good news to non-believers. Now that's classic Cognitive Dissonance!

Please like and share to help celebrate Cognitive Dissonance day. :-) Timeline Photos.

If you study psychology there is a very good chance that you will be introduced to the theory of cognitive dissonance. This robust theory suggests that a motivational state of inner tension is triggered by logically inconsistent ways of thinking.

Originally published in the Journal of Abnormal & Social Psychology, Cognitive Consequences of Forced Compliance by Leon Festinger & James Carlsmith was the first of numerous studies to corroborate the theory of cognitive dissonance. The premiss for this classic piece of research was to test what happens to a person's private opinion if he is forced to do or say something contrary to that opinion?

You can download and read this psychology classic for free via the following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/support-files/cognitive-dissonance.pdf. Timeline Photos.

Key definitions, history, topic areas, forensic psychology careers, free full-text articles and forensic psychology degree options are just some of the many topics and resources available at http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/ Timeline Photos.

Interview with Dr. Stephen Porter:

Dr. Stephen Porter is an academic and consultant in the area of psychology and law and is the Founding Director of the Centre for the Advancement of Psychological Science & Law (CAPSL) in Canada. He has published numerous scholarly articles on deception, psychopaths and violent behaviour, and forensic aspects of memory.

You can access our interview with Dr. Stephen Porter via the following link.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/steve-porter.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/

Interview with Joe Navarro:

Joe Navarro is recognized as one of the world’s foremost authorities on reading non-verbal communications and is regularly interviewed on programs such as NBC’s Today Show, Fox News, ABC’s Good Morning America, CBS’ Early Show, and for publications such as The Washington Post and Psychology Today.

You can access our interview with Joe Navarro via the following link.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/joe-navarro.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/

Interview with forensic psychologist Dr. Steve Porter.

Dr. Stephen Porter is an academic and consultant in the area of psychology and law. Steve is the Founding Director of the Centre for the Advancement of Psychological Science & Law (CAPSL) in Canada. He has published numerous scholarly articles on deception, psychopaths and violent behaviour, and forensic aspects of memory.

You can access the interview via the following link.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/steve-porter.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

I've just updated the paranormal psychology page over at the All About Psychology website, which includes a fascinating article from 1925 in which the great Houdini exposes the trickery of fake spirit mediums. See following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/paranormal-psychology.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Lots of brilliant examples of Inattentional blindness. Do you think you would have noticed the person swap?  Person Swap.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Forming Impressions of Personality by Solomon Asch (Free Full-Text)

Forming Impressions of Personality by Solomon Asch is a classic study in the psychology of interpersonal perception. The central tenet of this research is that particular information we have about a person, namely the traits we believe they possess, is the most important factor in establishing our overall impression of that person.

This is the journal article that introduces us to the concept of central versus peripheral traits and the "halo effect". Read/download it for free via the following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/solomon-asch.html. Timeline Photos.

See link below for a Q & A with acclaimed psychologist, researcher & micro expressions expert David Matsumoto Ph.D - includes access to a free full text copy of Dr. Matsumoto's article - Evaluating Truthfulness and Detecting Deception: New Tools to Aid Inverstigators.

http://www.all-about-body-language.com/david-matsumoto.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/

See link below to read - On The Witness Stand: Essays on Psychology & Crime - by Hugo Munsterberg, a pioneering work in the history of forensic psychology. Topics addressed include:

Illusions
The Memory of The Witness
The Detection of Crime
Untrue Confessions
Hypnotism & Crime
The Prevention of Crime 

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/hugo-munsterberg.html. Timeline Photos.
Compilation of clips showcasing some of psychology's most in(famous) experiments. In(famous) Psychology Experiments.

Sage publishers are offering free access to their most read Psychology and Counseling Articles until the 28th April. Full text titles available to download include:

Two-Year Outcomes for Children With Autism After the Cessation of Early Intensive Behavioral Intervention by Hanna Kovshoff, Richard P. Hastings, Bob Remington.

A Physical Activity Program Improves Behavior and Cognitive Functions in Children With ADHD: An Exploratory Study by Claudia Verret, Marie-Claude Guay, Claude Berthiaume, Phillip Gardiner, and Louise Béliveau.

Stress and Coping Activity: Reframing Negative Thoughts by Jamie S. Hughes, Mary K. Gourley, Laura Madson, and Katya Le Blanc.

Ethnocultural Aspects of PTSD: An Overview of Concepts, Issues,
and Treatments by Anthony J. Marsella Traumatology.

You can access all the articles available to download for free via the following link.

http://bit.ly/FreePsychArticles. Timeline Photos.

In 2005 the FBI’s National Center for the Analysis of Violent Crime, Behavioral Analysis Unit hosted a 5 day symposium on serial murder. Their goal was to bring together experts on serial murder in order to identify commonalities of knowledge.

One of the issues addressed during this unique symposium was the fact that the rarity of serial murder combined with inaccurate, anecdotal and fictional portrayals of serial killers has resulted in a number of common misconceptions arising. As a result of their deliberations, the expert panel identified 7 main serial killer myths, the details of which can be accessed via the following link.

http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/serial-killers.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Brief video featuring B.F Skinner discussing schedules of reinforcement and free will. Schedules of Reinforcement.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

2,600 articles anybody? The Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis is a psychology journal that publishes research about applications of the experimental analysis of behavior to problems of social importance.

All Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis issues from 1968 to the present day are freely accessible to the general public. See following link to access this outstanding free resource.

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/journals/309/ Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Excellent resource for anybody looking for free full text articles. Neural Plasticity is an international, interdisciplinary journal dedicated to the publication of articles related to all aspects of neural plasticity, with special emphasis on its functional significance as reflected in behavior and in psychopathology. 

Neural Plasticity publishes research and review articles from the entire range of relevant disciplines, including basic neuroscience, behavioral neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, biological psychology, and biological psychiatry. 

See following link to access all the 493 articles published to date.

http://www.hindawi.com/journals/np/contents/ Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Concepts of Trait and Personality is the latest title to be added to the psychology on Kindle collection.

Originally published in 1927 this classic article by Gordon W. Allport highlights the ambiguity surrounding attempts to characterize personality traits. Having done this, Allport then outlines how the term "trait" can be rescued from the confusion in which he believes it to be embedded.

You can view the full psychology on Kindle collection via the following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-on-kindle.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

The Power of Music (Free Full text).

Originally published in The Journal of Philosophy, Psychology and Scientific Methods in 1908, The Power of Music By Halbert Hains Britan is the latest addition to the psychology journal article collection. An initiative by the website http://www.all-about-psychology.com/ to make important, insightful and engaging publications freely available.

If you would like to read The Power of Music, you can do so via the following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/power-of-music.html

See link below to access all the titles in the psychology journal collection. 

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-journal-articles.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Psychology as the behaviorist views it was originally presented as a lecture by John B Watson at Columbia University in 1913. This landmark address would become known forever as the "behaviorist manifesto" and bestow on Watson the title of "father of behaviorism."

This classic publication can be read and downloaded for free via the following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/psychology-as-the-behaviorist-views-it.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Forming Impressions of Personality by Solomon Asch (Free Full-Text)

Forming Impressions of Personality by Solomon Asch is a classic study in the psychology of interpersonal perception. The central tenet of this research is that particular information we have about a person, namely the traits we believe they possess, is the most important factor in establishing our overall impression of that person.

This is the journal article that introduces us to the concept of central versus peripheral traits and the "halo effect" and you can read it in full for free via the following link.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/solomon-asch.html. Timeline Photos.

http://www.all-about-psychology.com/

Audio interview with Mark Safarik, an internationally recognized expert in the analysis and interpretation of violent criminal behavior who spent over half of his career as a behavioral crime analyst in the FBI’s National Center for Analysis of Violent Crime.

You can listen to the interview in full via the following link.

http://bit.ly/CriminalProfilerMarkSafarik

For anybody interested in learning more about criminal profiling, there are a number of pages dedicated to the topic over at the All About Forensic Psychology website (http://www.all-about-forensic-psychology.com/). Timeline Photos.

Free full-text copy of one of the most frequently Cited Journal Articles in Introductory Psychology Textbooks. Building on psychological research that maintained that short-term memory is restricted to just a few bits of information, this classic paper by George A Miller showed among other things how chunking could be employed to increase the restricted capacity of short-term memory. The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two: Some Limits on Our Capacity for Processing Information" is among the most frequently cited journal articles in introductory psychology textbooks. 

Building on psychological research that maintained that short-term memory is restricted to just a few bits of information, this famous paper by George A Miller showed among other things how chunking could be employed to increase the restricted capacity of short-term memory.
